text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Hospital &
Nursing Home Daily \-- Investigators publish new report on endocrinology.
According to news reporting out of Chengdu, People's Republic of China, by
NewsRx editors, research stated, "Cardiovascular diseases have become the
leading cause of human death. Aging is an independent risk factor for
cardiovascular diseases."

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from West China Second
University Hospital: "Cardiac aging is associated with maladaptation of
cellular metabolism, dysfunction (or senescence) of cardiomyocytes, a decrease
in angiogenesis, and an increase in tissue scarring (fibrosis). These events
eventually lead to cardiac remodeling and failure. Senescent cardiomyocytes
show the hallmarks of DNA damage, endoplasmic reticulum stress, mitochondria
dysfunction, contractile dysfunction, hypertrophic growth, and senescence-
associated secreting phenotype (SASP). Metabolism within cardiomyocytes is
essential not only to fuel the pump function of the heart but also to maintain
the functional homeostasis and participate in the senescence of
cardiomyocytes. The senescence of cardiomyocyte is also regulated by the non-
myocytes (endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and immune cells) in the local
microenvironment. On the other hand, the senescent cardiomyocytes alter their
phenotypes and subsequently affect the non-myocytes in the local
microenvironment and contribute to cardiac aging and pathological remodeling.
In this review, we first summarized the hallmarks of the senescence of
cardiomyocytes. Then, we discussed the metabolic switch within senescent
cardiomyocytes and provided a discussion of the cellular communications
between dysfunctional cardiomyocytes and non-myocytes in the local
microenvironment."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "We also addressed the
functions of metabolic regulators within non-myocytes in modulating myocardial
microenvironment. Finally, we pointed out some interesting and important
questions that are needed to be addressed by further studies."

For more information on this research see: Cardiomyocyte Senescence and
Cellular Communications Within Myocardial Microenvironments. _Frontiers in
Endocrinology_ , 2020,11. (Frontiers in Endocrinology -
<http://www.frontiersin.org/endocrinology>). The publisher for Frontiers in
Endocrinology is Frontiers Media S.A.

A free version of this journal article is available at
<https://doi.org/10.3389/fendo.2020.00280>.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting Xiaoqiang Tang, Key Laboratory of Birth Defects and Related
Diseases of Women and Children of MOE, State Key Laboratory of Biotherapy,
West China Second University Hospital, Sichuan University, Chengdu, People's
Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Pei-Heng Li,
Hou-Zao Chen.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Study Data from West China Second University Hospital Update Knowledge of Endocrinology (Cardiomyocyte Senescence and Cellular Communications Within Myocardial Microenvironments): Health and Medicine - Endocrinology
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Hospital & Nursing Home Daily -- Investigators publish new report on endocrinology. According to news reporting out of Chengdu, People’s Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, “Cardiovascular diseases have become the leading cause of human death. Aging is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular diseases.”

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from West China Second University Hospital: “Cardiac aging is associated with maladaptation of cellular metabolism, dysfunction (or senescence) of cardiomyocytes, a decrease in angiogenesis, and an increase in tissue scarring (fibrosis). These events eventually lead to cardiac remodeling and failure. Senescent cardiomyocytes show the hallmarks of DNA damage, endoplasmic reticulum stress, mitochondria dysfunction, contractile dysfunction, hypertrophic growth, and senescence-associated secreting phenotype (SASP). Metabolism within cardiomyocytes is essential not only to fuel the pump function of the heart but also to maintain the functional homeostasis and participate in the senescence of cardiomyocytes. The senescence of cardiomyocyte is also regulated by the non-myocytes (endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and immune cells) in the local microenvironment. On the other hand, the senescent cardiomyocytes alter their phenotypes and subsequently affect the non-myocytes in the local microenvironment and contribute to cardiac aging and pathological remodeling. In this review, we first summarized the hallmarks of the senescence of cardiomyocytes. Then, we discussed the metabolic switch within senescent cardiomyocytes and provided a discussion of the cellular communications between dysfunctional cardiomyocytes and non-myocytes in the local microenvironment.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “We also addressed the functions of metabolic regulators within non-myocytes in modulating myocardial microenvironment. Finally, we pointed out some interesting and important questions that are needed to be addressed by further studies.”

For more information on this research see: Cardiomyocyte Senescence and Cellular Communications Within Myocardial Microenvironments. Frontiers in Endocrinology, 2020,11. (Frontiers in Endocrinology - http://www.frontiersin.org/endocrinology). The publisher for Frontiers in Endocrinology is Frontiers Media S.A.

A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3389/fendo.2020.00280.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Xiaoqiang Tang, Key Laboratory of Birth Defects and Related Diseases of Women and Children of MOE, State Key Laboratory of Biotherapy, West China Second University Hospital, Sichuan University, Chengdu, People’s Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Pei-Heng Li, Hou-Zao Chen.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
